title: discover-places-keeping-vegan-food-scene-thriving
story: Tchai-OvnaHidden down a wee cobbled lane in the heart of Glasgowrsquos West End, on entering Tchai-Ovna you would be forgiven for thinking you are stepping into a Himalayan tea room or a Turkish bazar.Tchai-Ovna was founded in  by a group of Glasgow University students tired of the prevalent alcohol culture. When they first discovered the location, an old th C stables, it was badly in need of some t.l.c. but its magical, Bohemian, offbeat atmosphere was perfect. Too young to get business funding, with help from friends and the community they invested their student loans and refurbished the premises, keeping as many original features as possible: cobbled floors, horsersquos tethers etc. The vegetarian speciality tea house they created was only supposed to last a year, but almost twenty years on it is now a firmly established Glasgow institution."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Tchai-Ovna","description": "Tchai-Ovna","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media dSMDgrx poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests dSMDgrx.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Today the menu represents a broad swathe of cultures including Mexican, Arabic and Indian. It is produced by award winning vegetarian specialists the chipotle chilli won an award for one of the best chillis in the West End, and it is completely vegan. The vegan curry, produced by Balbirs Restaurants celebrated Punjabi chefs is hearty, tasty and authentic. Whilst you are enjoying your meal you can partake in one of around  speciality teas, all Tchai-Ovna own brand, and many of them blended in house and to order. They also retail many of the teas in the shop and online as well as wholesale across Scotland.Many know Tchai-Ovna as a much loved community hub, where people of all ages and backgrounds meet to socialise, play board games and listen to local, and international, live music acts and performances. It is welcoming, informal and unpretentious. Perhaps it is for this reason that even well-known celebs have become patrons. Belle and Sebastienrsquos album art for Dear Catastrophe Waitress was shot here, members of Franz Ferdinand stop by when they are not on tour, and Scarlett Johansson likes it so much she has been twice.Whatever your reason, be sure to stop by for a cuppa when you are in Glasgow.www.tchaiovna Otago LaneGlasgowG PBOpen am-pm every day----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Hanoi Bike ShopVietnamese food was vegan friendly before vegans were vegan. The streets of Hanoi are filled with vegetables and fresh produce that many of us here in Scotland have never heard of, let alone tasted. Plant-based food is everywhere in Vietnam and at the Hanoi Bike Shop they continue this tradition without ever sacricing taste or flavour.The little restaurant is situation just off Byres Road in the West End. The twinkly lights, Vietnamese flags and vintage bikes will draw you down the lane but once you get through the door donrsquot be put by the smell, they swear itrsquos not lsquowet dogrsquo or lsquohamster cagesrsquo as some TripAdvisor reviews would have you think. Fish sauce is a staple in Vietnamese cuisine and does leave a lasting impression on the senses. Although they use Tamariin all of their vegan dishes the fresh pho broths are always on the boil and help to give Hanoi its distinctive odour.Hanoi Bike Shop chefs have created a vegan menu influenced by seasonal availability of local produce as well as the salty, sweet, sour and spicy balance of Vietnamese cuisine.The star of course, is their organic handmade tofu, which is carefully, simmered, strained and pressed daily in house.Hanoirsquos vegan menu consists of over twenty freshly prepared dishes ranging from Kimchi Spring Rolls and Daikon and Soya Bean Cakes to Chilli Glazed Sesame Rice Cakes and Curried Banana.They implore all customers to adopt their dining motto lsquosharing is caringrsquo and go for the lsquoFeed Mersquo option. The passionate staff will listen to your likes and dislikes and design a bespoke banquet around you. Then you just sit back, relax and let the banquet begin.www.hanoibikeshopInstagram www.instagram hanoibikeshop Facebook www.facebook TheHanoiBikeShop booking.resdiary widget Standard HanoiBikeShop  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------OM Sweet OMOM Sweet OM is a vibrant haven, tucked behind Central Station in Oswald St, in the centre of Glasgow, committed to the art of sustainable happiness and conscious living. The charity is set up to promote well-being which will empower you to experience a higher taste in le thus satisfying your physical, emotional and spiritual needs.Inspired by the ancient Bhakti tradition of Vedic culture they integrate and unite the ious yoga systems to form a lestyle to benefit yourself, those around you, the planet and all of its ied inhabitants.OM Sweet OM practice Ahimsa, the principle of non-violence, in their vegan dishes and lestyle to increase compassion for all living beings and reduce harm to our environment. A plant-based diet is crucial for their inidual wellbeing and that of the planet itself.Most of their events feature vegan meals and all of the meals served in OM Sweet OM are lovingly prepared by the cooks at Krishna Eco Farm www.facebook krishnaecofarm  to a very high standard, often using produce fresh from the gardens. The most popularevent is the Vegan All You Can Eat Feast where everyone is personally served a delicious thali-style meal until fully satisfied...and then dessert. They have a thriving programme providing free vegan food on the streets of Glasgow via the project Food for Scotland www.facebook foodscotland. This is aimed at homeless people and also promote plant-based diets."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "OM Sweet OM","description": "OM Sweet OM","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media PfqkSp poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests PfqkSp.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Just as the body needs nourishment by vegan superfood, they also offer yoga classes to maintain a good flow of healthy energy. They have classes to suit all levels of practitioners and even entry level by donation to encourage newcomers to try. Award-winning yoga teacher, Daniel Gronan, has several lively classes featuring vinyasa yoga and mantra movement.For those wanting to e deeper into philosophy, there are classes available to discover and discuss timeless yoga wisdom of India. The western giants of modern philosophy all take their roots from the Sanskrit teachings. Many psychologists and neurologists are realising the benefits of mantra sound vibrations on our well-being.In conjunction with Krishna Eco Farm, retreats are available to immerse oneself in yoga, mindfulness and mantra meditation in the beautul countryside of Lesmahagow, with wonderful vegan meals.OM Sweet OM, Food for Scotland and Krishna Eco Farm are all projects of ISKCON Scotland, charity number SC.www.omsweetomwww.facebook omsweetomglasgowwww.instagram omsweetom.glasgow----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Kalpna Indian Vegan and Vegetarian RestaurantOpen since , Kalpna Indian Vegan and Vegetarian Restaurant stands as one of Edinburghrsquos most established Institution. During this time, it has won several awards for excellence in Indian and vegan and vegetarian categories.In their dishes they use only the freshest ingredients, which, wherever possible has been sourced locally.They remain a family run restaurant serving high quality Indian vegan and vegetarian food to the people of Scotland for over a quarter of a century and many of their customers have been visiting the restaurant since their childhood. The restaurant is often referred to as an institution rather than a restaurant.The owner is passionate about a vegetarian and vegan lestyle and the family is dedicated to introducing people to the pleasures of Indian vegetarian food. The chefs at Kalpna draw on their vast experience in Punjabi, Gujrati and South Indian delicacies.www.kalpnarestaurant--------------------------PicnicPicnic was opened in late  by Michelle Morrow, as a healthy and ethical alternative to the many other food outlets in the Merchant City area. With a  per cent cruelty free menu - yet appealing to vegans and nonvegans alike - Picnic quickly established itself as an extremely popular place for a fantastic, healthy breakfast, a delicious lunch or luscious slice of cake and a cup of co#ee.Picnic serves a wide range of freshly prepared, healthy vegan food, including delectable homemade wa#es, salads, wraps, soup, curry, sandwiches, juices and some of the best smoothies in Glasgow.At weekends and on public holidays, Picnic serve a phenomenal full cooked breakfast, which, although healthy, is every bit as satisfying as the traditional full Scottish. De#nitely something to try,yoursquore in the mood for some guilt-free, comfort food."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Picnic","description": "Picnic","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media JrWMW poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests JrWMW.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Open seven days a week, Picnic is known not only for fantastic food and beverages but also for its bright, cheery decor. This is all backed up by attentive, friendly and welcoming service. Everybody is welcome and you can even bring your dog along with you.Naturally, Picnic has been a big hit with Glasgowrsquos rising number of vegans. However, yoursquoll also #nd many non-vegan regulars frequenting the cafe, all enjoying the terri#c food and the friendly vibe. Picnic is very highly rated across all major online review s. It is currently the top-rated vegan eatery on Happy Cowin Glasgow. Picnic is also ranked in the top  globally by the same website.Going into its rd year - as Glasgow City Centrersquos #rst  per cent vegan cafe - Picnic continues to set the standard for healthy and ethical food.Be sure to pay Picnic a visit, next time you are in the Merchant City area.www.picnicwww.instagram picnic.glasgow www.facebook picnic.glasgow

title: energy-broker-boxfish-set-expansion-push
story: Steve De la Rosa, managing directorof energy consultancy Boxfish, which for nearly quarter of a century was Business Cost Consultants, is looking to grow the West End business signicantly after a sweeping rebrand.The firm launched the revamp at the turn of the year and has had a favourable response.:Scotlandrsquos sht towards green future lsquowill cost poundbnMr De la Rosa said the company acts as ldquothe backroom operations for a companyrsquos utility needs with businesses such as Trespass and Farmfoods on board.He said: ldquoWersquore looking at acquisitionsas a way to expand the business and we are actively looking at the market to see where there may be opportunity for us to look at other operations that are similar to us, that might be in the right space for us.But wersquore doing a lot of work in England now, and it might well be that we need something around Leeds, Bradford, Manchester maybe. So wersquore looking at that right now.ldquoLondon is also picking up for us. We deal with the Ballymore Group working across about five or six sites at the moment.ldquoThe type of services we offer include the procurement of all the utilities, and management, and bureau management of those backroom requirements.ldquoWe give a rounded service, that means that wersquore basically the backroom operations for a companyrsquos utility needs. Then we have legislative compliance, which will be anything that the government brings out around carbon or energy saving, or renewables.The chief executive said the company is ahead on sales projections and ldquothings are moving well.:Amazon target Scottish site for game changing wind farm plansThe firm is looking at doubling its staff of  over the next three years, and Mr De la Rosa added: ldquoWe are based in Finnieston in the West End on a site that looks like it may be developed for flats at some time in the next three years.ldquoSo, Irsquom looking at other opportunities in Glasgow for relocation. Wersquore looking at hiring now. The rebrandrsquos been a long project. Itrsquos taken us since before Christmas. Therersquos still stuff to be done. Yoursquoll see a delivery vehicle driving around Glasgow and therersquos lots of other things that wersquore going to be doing to promote that.ldquoNext is to ensure that we have all our ducks in a row, with the right qualied staff, for the new revenue streams that wersquove targeted.ldquoWersquore able to do everything that wersquove got on our plate, but wersquove got some new ones that wersquore going to advertise, once wersquove got all the correct staff in the place.He said there can be pitfalls in the sector, and pointed to Utilitywise, which had to reimburse a supplier pound. million after lower-than-anticipated usage before going into administration.:Ministers admit more needs to be done to meet Scottish climate targetMr De la Rosa said Boxfish and other consultancies are mooting a specic regulator for the sector. The firm has linked with other brokers to seek the introduction of formal regulation in the energy brokerage industry.He said: ldquoThere needs to be an official complaints process, set up with an ombudsman, where a contract can be frozen at a beneficial rate, while the deal is being reviewed by a third party.ldquoI think therersquos need for regulation in the industry and most of the issues would go away with proper regulation.ldquoBut it affects the good businesses, and there are good businesses out there. You know, wersquore not the only one thatrsquos here to try to put the client in the right space.ldquoWersquore a business thatrsquos been around for about just under  years, and wersquove got over  years of experience within the business in utilities.:Energy regulator toughens checks on firms after wave of failuresThe company made the move to undertake a repackaging, which is not without risk, after it found the original name didnrsquot stand out enough.He said: ldquoWe decided that we want to future-proof our business, and by doing that we invested heavily in the business in advance of that rebrand.ldquoThatrsquos in equipment, office, all our staff, and wersquore doing inidual training with them to get them professional qualications in procurement, and auditing services, and thatrsquos something that is moving at pace now.ldquoWhen we actually did the investigation into the market, we found that our name of lsquoBusiness Cost Consultantsrsquo had been tacked on as a tagline to many other businesses, who would be lsquoblah blah energy: business cost consultantsrsquo.ldquoSo we were getting lost in the noise.ldquoOur marketing agency put Boxfish together and itrsquos been very successful. People donrsquot forget it, which is a good thing.The name was chosen as the boxfish is ldquoone of the oceanrsquos most energy-efficient creatures.He said: ldquoWhat are the challenges  Well obviously the challenge is in making sure that our clients, our existing client base, wasnrsquot rattled by the change, and we had to ensure that we kept our cards close to our chest, before launch, because it could have been spun up by others as a negative thing.ldquoWe got past that, there was no problem, and our clients have very much bought into the new ethos of Boxfish, and who we are now.ldquoWersquove evolved over the years and I think wersquore a much better equipped company for the fast moving utility market.QAQ What countries have you most enjoyed travelling to, for business or leisure, and why A Irsquove been lucky in that Irsquove travelled a lot but the three places that always stick with me have been Nantucket Island, US, just off of Boston as an ex whaling station it has lots of history and is tiny in that you can cycle it end to end in an hour, itrsquos very peaceful in the tourist off season again Byron Bay, Australia, in the off-season takes some beating sitting on a deserted beach watching the whales swim by and the dolphins playing with the surfers. Work wise Jakarta, Indonesia, was amazing as itrsquos an unbelievable city though most memorable for being caught in city wide flooding up to my chest watching a Rolls Royce float by while kids surfed the flood waters!Q When you were a child, what was your ideal job  Why did it appeal A I wanted to be a chef as I loved cooking and still do though I donrsquot think Irsquoll be opening an eatery soon.Q What was your biggest break in business A Working for the Department of International Development where I had to learn quickly how to manage and work with a global range of stakeholders delivering critical aid programmes.Q What was your worst moment in business A When Pelamis Wave Power got into trouble with funding and laid the majority of staff off.Q Who do you most admire and why A I once met David Miliband when being interviewed for a role at the International Rescue Committee. He was really switched on and very genuine about his concerns within the aid sector.I was very impressed with him and Irsquove followed his work with the IRC ever since.Q What book are you reading Break Point by Ollie Ollerton and what music are you listening to A I donrsquot really listen to music preferring podcasts on history or science.Q What was the last film you saw A Wreck it Ralph Breaks the Internet .

title: msps-back-plans-tackle-euro-2020-ticket-touts
story: Members of the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Culture Committee unanimously approved legislation designed to protect fans from paying for rip-off tickets.The Uefa Championship Bill was introduced at Holyrood last month as Glasgow prepares to host fixtures as part of the tournament next yearIt will prohibit the unauthorised sale of tickets for the tournament which are in excess of face value or with a view to making a profit.Other measures in the Bill include the banning of unauthorised street trading and unauthorised advertising in event zones in the city.Criminal offences will also be createdfor ticket touting, unauthorised street trading and advertising, with enforcement officers given powers to tackle such offences.Exemptions will be made to allow activities such as busking and collections for charity within designated fan zones during the competition.Committee convener Joan McAlpine said: ldquoThe committee recognises the signicant cultural, economic and social opportunities that hosting part of Euro  presents to Scotland.ldquoThe Bill provides the tools necessary to make sure the event is a success and the committee unanimously supports the principles of the Bill.ldquoIt is welcoming to see that action will be taken to allow buskers and charity collectors to operate during the tournament.ldquoTravelling football fans are in for a real treat when they visit and soak up the unique atmosphere that will be created.Deputy committee convener Claire Baker added: ldquoThe committee has considered this Bill to an extremely tight timescale in recognition of the benefit that hosting Euro  matches will bring to Scotland.ldquoTicket touting is an unacceptable act which takes advantage of fans. The committee fully supports the measures proposed which send a clear message that such actions should become a thing of the past.

title: ancient-celtic-healing-well-gets-long-awaited-spring-clean
story: But the modern world of backpackers and coach tours has taken its toll on Clootie Well in Munlochy, the Black Isle, where legend has it a rag or cloot dipped in the healing waters and tied to a tree can cure sickness or ailment.Now officials from Forestry and Land Scotland have teamed up with community groups for one of Scotlandrsquos most unusual clean-up operations.In a bid to preserve the site and protect the environment, they removed  bags of unsuitable offerings last month, including underwired bras, polyester flags, umbrellas, sunglasses ndash and even a medical back brace.But locals were careful to maintain the unique atmosphere of a place steeped in mystery and long associated with pre-Christian traditions.John Stott, chair of the local Knockbain Community Council, said the woods surrounding the well had become a mess.He said: ldquoIt had got out of control, and the cloots werenrsquot actually biodegradable, by and large.ldquoA lot of the material, as most modern materials are now, wasnrsquot biodegradable, therefore itrsquos never going to go anywhere.Mr Stott said the site had expanded as it grew more popular with backpackers and tour companies.He said: ldquoIt had started to spread out to the point where it was taking over a huge section of woodland, as opposed to the actual Clootie Well site itself, which is, letrsquos say,  yards by  yards or something like that.ldquoThe cloots had actually extended out to  or  yards. It was just a huge expansion of the site.ldquoBut at the actual site round the Clootie Well itself, we didnrsquot remove anything other than possibly inappropriate stuff such as umbrellas, sunglasses, a pair of trainers.ldquoThere was a colossal amount of stuff around that was totally inappropriate.However, Mr Stott said those involved were careful to show respect to people who had placed genuine offerings around the well.He added: ldquoItrsquos peoplersquos wishes, peoplersquos hopes, obviously, that they are hanging on these trees.ldquoWe did it with as much respect and dignity as we possibly could.He continued: ldquoThe idea basically is you hang up a wee bit of cloth, and as that cloth biodegrades it draws away the illness of the person who you have hung it up for.ldquoSo thatrsquos the theory,you like, or the history of it. But things like sunglasses are clearly never, ever going to biodegrade.He said those who initially expressed concerns over the clean-up were reassured once the purpose of it was made clear.And he suggested an annual drive to keep the surrounding area tidy could be in order in future.He added: ldquoI wouldnrsquot quite say we havenrsquot scratched the surface, but Irsquom quite sure the same exercise could be done again and it still wouldnrsquot actually affectthe character.ldquoI would like to see some kind of annual event ndash done tastefully, done as a family thing, just to make sure that we keep on top of the non-biodegradables and we donrsquot end up back in the same situation.Clootie wells ndash or sites drawing on similar traditions ndash can be found where in Scotland and the UK, but few possess the unsettling atmosphere found in Munlochy.Its strange power even inspired elements of Ian Rankinrsquos novel The Naming of the Dead.While it is associated with a holy well, such healing traditions pre-date Christianityand the area has become an important site for those with a iety of beliefs and none.Maree Morrison, of Forestry and Land Scotland, said  volunteers took part in the clean-up from the local communities of Munlochy, Avoch and Knockbain, as well as from further across the Black Isle and Easter Ross.She said: ldquoThe site was expanding rapidly, with the surrounding woodland being badly affected by non-biodegradable items as they built up over the years.ldquoThere were cloots tied around trees and information posts in the car park.ldquoThe items had crept out from the well up to  metres out into the woodland, and the local community felt that it was getting too much and was detracting from the traditional nature of the healing well.Ms Morrison said volunteers removed a iety of unsuitable items including empty dog poo bags, entire pairs of jeans, a window blind and even an electrical sander.Forestry and Land Scotland is now requesting that any offerings left at the site are restricted to natural cotton or wool. Any plastics, polyesters or other materials will be removed.

title: If Labour win  it  39 ll be less like Venezuela than Britain circa 1974
story: Jeremy Corbyn was also talking tough this week. He identied some of the capitalist criminals Labour is coming for, including Sir Jim Ratclfe of Ineos. Though itrsquos not clear under what law the polluting plutocrats could be prosecuted.So, is this class war in the UK  Are we on the road to Venezuela  Whatever the polls say, a Labour victory this Christmas is quite possible with Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party now splitting the Tory vote. There is a powerful mood for change in Britain. But what would a Labour government actually look like We have never had such an avowedly radical Prime Minister ndash not even in , when Labour was led by a small ldquoc conservative, Clement Attlee. However, Labour reality would be rather dferent from the rhetoric. Burrow into Labourrsquos policies, and what emerges looks more like reheated social democracy, circa, than a Bolshevik revolution.For a start, we can largely ignore the issue that ided the party so bitterly in recent times: nuclear weapons. Jeremy Corbyn may be a lelong member of CND, but Labour is no longer a unilateralist party. Its  manesto committed a Labour government to renewing Trident almost indefinitely.But Corbyn will still enter Number  with a raft of left-wing policies, from seizing corporate assets to abolishing private schools as well as taxing the rich until the pips squeak. However, many of the headline policies will never make it to first reading, let alone the statute book.Abolishing schools like Eton would involve y court action, not least from faith schools and the home school movement, who might also be affected. Labour is more likely to confine its assault on educational privilege to axeing tax reliefs worth about pound. billionSimilarly, seizing % of the shares of companies with more than  employees would be fiercely resisted in the courts by shareholders. They have deep pockets. I suspect Labour would confine itself to increasing corporate taxes, ending zero-hours contracts and restoring trades union rights ndash all of which are eminently doable.Indeed, looking behind the radical rhetoric, much of Labourrsquos policy agenda is surprisingly modest, viewed from Scotland. Measures like free personal care, abolishing university tuition fees, childcare for three and four-year-olds, scrapping the right to buy, lting the benefits cap and the bedroom tax ndash these are all achievable.Indeed, the Scottish Parliament has already achieved them, bar the welfare cap. Nicola Sturgeon will no doubt remind the Labour leader of this repeatedly in coming weeks.Nationalisation is a policy that used to be seen as ldquoloony left but is no longer. Taking rail into public ownership shouldnrsquot be too much of a problem, since Network Rail, which owns the track and signalling, is already in public hands. The service franchises could be replaced as they come up for renewal, without needing to hand billions in compensation to Virgin and the rest.Waterand energy would pose greater problems, not least because most of our energy companies are foreign-owned ndash often, ironically, by state-owned bodies. But with a good wind it should be possible for Labour to find a way. Public attitudes to public ownership of utilities have changed out of all recognition since the s.Similarly, there is broad public support for Labourrsquos Green New Deal. A majority of voters agrees there is a climate emergency. Though they may not agree with the measures needed to tackle it.Labour is not going the full Extinction Rebellion route of making Britain zero carbon by . But its own policy, passed at conference, is still pretty radical. It commits a Labour government to making Britain zero carbon by . Thatrsquos only five years longer.We are talking about the most radical change to our lestyles since the industrial revolution. Labourrsquos policy would mean decarbonising transport, home heating and agriculture in a decade. Millions of cars would have to be scrapped along with millions of home boilers. Air travel would all but cease.Labour promises a huge investment in renewable industries to compensate, but that is unlikely to replace the jobs lost in the car industry, oil and gas, road haulage and retail.So expect the Green New Deal to become somewhat lighter green in government. There is likely to be a rt between the Thunberg-supporting ldquode-growthers and Labour MPs, who traditionally see economic growth as the best way to address poverty and inequality.However, Britain already has a rather good record on eliminating greenhouse emissions, and this will continue, albeit with the  target reduced to % net zero.In sum, Labour offers a practical social democratic programme which could be very attractive to voters, especially younger ones. However there is one very big problem: Brexit.Labour is committed to negotiating a new Withdrawal Deal to replace Boris Johnsonrsquosand to putting this to another Brexit referendum. This will consume a vast amount of political capital and will surely dominate the first year of a Labour government.Corbyn wants to reintroduce the customs union and Brussels would probably agree to that. But Labour also wants close regulatory alignment with the European Single Market, which the EU  would probably reject. If Britain wants to be in the single market, it will have to join the single market, probably via the European Economic Area, along with Norway.Labour could go along with that in the end, since it wants friction-free access to the EU markets. Single market membership would solve the Irish border problem, for sure.But it would also mean Britain continuing to contribute to the EU Budget, while having no say over decisions taken by Brussels. Customs union membership requires oversight by the European Court of Justice, which will displease many.But that wouldnrsquot be the main problem. If Labour got this wonderful deal, including workersrsquo rights and environmental standards, and got it through Parliament , would it really then campaign against it in the confirmatory referendum Interviewers have largely stopped asking this question, because they never get an answer, but Europe remains a huge question mark hanging over Labourrsquos government agenda.Labour is still a Brexit party, though you wouldnrsquot know it to listen to most MPs. Many figures in the party are closet Brexiteers, like Jeremy Corbyn himself. Others are openly pro-Brexit, like the party chairman Ian Lavery and the MPs who voted for Boris Johnsonrsquos deal.Equally dedicated Remainers ndash mostly Blairites and supporters of the deputy leader Tom Watson ndash would fight back, insisting that Labour effectively promised to back Remain in the General Election. Brexit wrangling could delay the confirmatory referendum and ide the party, just as it split the Tories.Corbynrsquos enemies will ignite further ision by condemning him as anti-Semitic. It will take immense powers of leadership to prevent a Labour government being halted in its radical tracks by Brexit.The question for voters is: does Jeremy Corbyn possess it

title: dark-materials-series-one-episode-one-review
story: OF the many mysteries spun by Philip Pullmanrsquos fantasy epic, one looms large. Why, despite shting phenomenal amounts in novel form, some  million sold to date, and being a relative success on stage, has His Dark Materials never lit up the screen successfully Some pound million was spent on a , all bells and whistles movie which, praise for armoured polar bears and Nicole Kidman aside, failed to fly. Now the BBC and HBO have splashed a rumoured pound million on an eight part adaptation for television.Worth it  While first impressions were favourable, that is still a lot of money. One and a half new BBC Scotland channels to be precise, or , licence fees for over s.Jack Thorne, the writer of Shameless and Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, was in charge of the adaptation. He gave little quarter to anyone unfamiliar with the novels. After a brief introduction covering the all-powerful ruling elite, known as the Magisterium, and a prophecy about a special child, we were pitched into a world very much like this world, yet somehow not. Welcome to the endless strangeness and complexities of Pullmanrsquos universe.Previous adaptations have fallen down in trying to get across the trilogyrsquos many and complex themes too soon. Wisely, this production homed in instead on the ldquodaemons, the spirit animals that encapsulate the souls of the humans to which they are attached. Scientist and explorer Lord Asriel James McAvoy, one of several Scots in the cast including James Cosmo and Gary Lewis has a very cool snow leopard as his daemon. His orphaned niece, Lyra, the child on whom so much will depend, has a stoat. Who doesnrsquot love a super furry animal that can talk British-Spanish actress Dafne Keen is excellent as the fearless, inquisitive Lyra, her dark features calling to mind the heroine of Panrsquos Labyrinth. McAvoy makes an awesome adventurer, never happier than when there is a swash to be buckled.Asriel has just blown in from the frozen north with tales of a mysterious substance he calls ldquodust. The existence of this material, which appears to conceal other worlds, is contrary to the Magisteriumrsquos teachings. It is the kind of information, indeed, that could topple empires.The mentions of ldquodust had unfortunate comic echoes of the Little Britain sketch about a slimming group leader who tells members that dust is all they can eatthey want to lose weight. The daemons, for all they were delightful in the main, took a while to get used to. When we could see their lips move it was obvious they were talking when we could not, their seemingly disembodied voices only added to the mounting confusion.Just when the story showed signs of slipping away, something happened that bodes well for any television drama: Ruth Wilson rocked up to play the mesmerising and beautul Mrs Coulter. Offering Lyra a job and the chance to move to London, the character played by the star of Luther and The Affair seems a dream come true for motherless Lyra. But her daemon is a gorgeous but terrying golden monkey - so make of that business what you will.By episode end, Asriel was racing back to the North, and scores of others were heading to London in search of vanished children. With armoured polar bears and Lin-Manuel Mirandastill to come, it would be a brave soul indeed who bailed on His Dark Materials this early. Keep the faith.Available on iPlayer

title: letters-false-promises-justify-snps-push-indyref2
story: Jeremy Corbyn claims this is a once-in-a-generation General Election, the Lib Demsrsquo Nick Clegg claimed that the  EU referendum was ldquoa once in a generation event and the Tory Government has proposed that Northern Ireland voters should have the opportunity to determine their constitutional future every four years.The  promises made by the No side in  included Ruth Davidson saying the only way to guarantee EU membership was to vote No, Gordon Brown promising that a No vote would mean a near-federal Scotland when powers have been removed from our Scottish Parliament and Boris Johnson has even threatened to take control of Scotlandrsquos NHS despite it performing much better than in Wales under Labour or the Tory run NHS in England which is facing increased privatisation.As well as the SNP holding a triple democratic mandate for a second referendum, we should remember that Scotland rarely gets the government most of us vote for in any UK General Election and normal rules donrsquot apply when the SNP become the third largest grouping at Westminster as evidenced by TV companies failing to give the SNP their proper status in UK wide news coverage or on ldquonational political programmes or debates.Fraser Grant, Edinburgh.NEIL Mackay discusses democracy in the UK regarding the EU membership result and states that another confirmatory vote referendum should be held, now that the details and probable effects of the last one have surfaced politics is to rip it up and start again, The Herald, October . Does he think that would be a fine example of democracy From the start the vote referendum was not sufficiently clear on the implications of leaving as no prior discussions appear to have been held with EU member states. No details were given on any options we could have with trading within the EU and where worldwide, in effect a sort of fait accompli. No comments were made whatsoever over what must have been blindingly obvious regarding border controls, in particular the Northern Ireland Eire one. That was the point when consultations with the ordinary people should have been made, before the vote and not now after the horse has bolted as Mr Mackay suggests.We have already had a ldquoonce in a letime vote regarding independence which the SNP is determined to hold again, so does he suggest we should follow suit with the Leave Remain EU one and throw democracy out with the bath water I voted Remain but grudgingly accepted the decision as that was the majorityrsquos wish. We now appear to be running the risk of those who feel denied their own wish to just re-run votes until they achieve their own desired result which, with such close results in both referendums, is a recipe for unrest. What should now be done is to discuss changes to the way we vote to give more meaningful results in future rather than the one vote either way first past the post system we currently have.George Dale, Beith.IF there is ever to be an Indyref the question to be asked must be fair, unbiased and easily understood.As evidenced by the question posed in the Brexit referendum, the opinion of the Electoral Commission is that a simple Yes No question is unfair as it contains an inherent bias in favour of the positivity of Yes against the negativity of No. It is encouraging therefore that Holyroodrsquos cross-party finance and constitution committee has recognised this in calling for more scrutiny of the question to be asked in any Indyref, instead of simply rubber-stamping the underhand attempt by the SNP to gain advantage by repeating the Yes No question asked in  .In demanding Indyref, it is clear that the objective of the SNP is to leave the UK union and join the EU, but there are concerns that a Leave  Remain question might confuse some as it carries echoes of Brexit. One question which goes to the heart of the matter and adopts the style used in  would be ldquoShould Scotland be part of the UK or part of the EU  UK or EU. There is no bias in the question and the choice could not be clearer.Alan Fitzpatrick, Dunlop.THE result of the election will be, in Scotland, a barometer of attitudes towards both Brexit and Scottish secession. It will be interesting to see how many of the SNPrsquos habitual voters who chose to leave the EU will remain SNP voters. A figure of around one-third of SNP voters represents Brexiters. Those seeking to support a Remain party have an easy choice: vote LibDem. Yet for those who oppose secession from the UK there really is only one choice: evenit means holding onersquos nose, one must vote for the party best-placed to defeat the SNP candidate. That will normally be the candidate who came second in , although in some cases, such as Ross, Cromarty and Skye ndash the constituency of Ian Blackford ndash it will not. That constituency has a strong Lib Dem heritage, and Remainers can vote Lib Dem happily.Nicola Sturgeon has made it clear that the issue in this election is Scotlandrsquos place in the UK. This is allied to a  claim that a Scotland could remain in the EU. Pro-Union people need to vote, and to vote for the party best-placed to unseat an SNP MP or to prevent an SNP candidate from winning.Jill Stephenson, EH.WHATEVER view we might hold about Brexit most people in Scotland must find it of great importance that we must defend our NHS. Our health service is under attack from two angles. First US health care companies want to get into health care contracts in the UK to make profits from that, and also the big drug companies in the US want to force the NHS to pay more for drugs, indeed as much as an additional pound billion for starters to get us level with prices in the US.So this is a time to look at our politicians now seeking our votes and make an important judgment. In a vote in the Westminster Parliament to protect the NHS the Tories predictably voted against, but the Liberals abstained. Now we know where the Tories stand on the NHS, they will sell it offthey get a deal they like with the US. So why did the Liberals not support the NHS, can Jo Swinson explain this to us when she is looking for Scottish votes Andy Anderson, Saltcoats.IF I hear any more politicians telling me that at last we will be able to use our vote to determine what party will win and get on with Brexit, I will despair. We have already done that ndash in General Elections, in referenda, and in local elections and European elections ndash but to no avail. Our politicians donrsquot give a toss who we elect or what we want, and at the moment it would appear that it would be extremely possible that a government will be elected ndash probably another minority government and we will start  in exactly the same situation where we find ourselves just now.I mean, letrsquos look at our choices. A party led by a despotic, bully-boy private school pupil, who thinks he is still at school, and held to account not by his members or electorate, but by an evil unelected manipulator who lurks in the shadows. A party led by a devoted Marxist who at least admits to his beliefs , and leads another ided main party which was once a great party. A party led by an unelected and unopposed leader, anxious to talk about nothing but Brexit to avoid scrutiny over what has happened to all the countryrsquos money when its services continue to fall and implode. A party led by a leader who resolutely refuses to live up to the word ldquodemocrat, which is part of her partyrsquos name, but which she and her party members have redefined as ldquodemocrat as long as you agree with us. A party led by a leader determined to leave the European Community at whatever cost, and who seems to appear on television and radio more than any other politician, despite him not holding a seat.You kindly printed a letter which I sent to you at the time of this yearrsquos European elections, when for the first time in my le, I refused to vote for any candidate , and asked sincerely: why we do not have a box in our ballot papers which allows us to vote, but at the same time express our opposition to the candidates and or parties who wish our votes  Compulsory voting should be introduced to this country as soon as possible, so that we could become like all eligible Australian citizens, for example, who are required to register to vote, to actually vote in all of its elections, and are penalisedthey do not vote. Were this system in place in the United Kingdom right now, we would perhaps discover that those of us who voted our disgust or protestations at politicians today attained  per cent  per cent  per cent of the vote, and maybe ndash just maybe ndash some of our politicians would waken up and take notice that our country is not all about them, but about all of us. I donrsquot think that would ever happen, though, do you Walter Paul, Glasgow G.WITH the election called for December  we have the problems of the dark days and nights potential weather disruptions, cancelled ferries and flights, road closures from snow, flu bugs and other hazards for people living in rural Scotland in particular. However, a postal vote will solve many of the problems.We have plenty of time to apply online or at our local council offices.The postal votes do not need to be sent in right away so we have plenty of time to find out what the political party manestos contain and check out the facts.Young people in Scotland who got the vote at  cannot vote in UK elections until they are . Voting at  and  has worked with no problems in Scotland since  and the public have been so impressed with thousands of young climate change protesters, led by Greta Thunberg. She has just announced that she will not accept any more awards for her campaigning as she and the children of the world do not need awards, they need urgent climate change action, now.All of us, the young and old, need to make sure that we are registered for voting in December and that we get out and vote or send in a postal vote in this the most important election in my  years.Max Cruickshank, Glasgow G.

title: islanders-happiest-scotland-according-new-survey
story: They may have an image of being slightly dour, a bit weather-beaten, stuck in the middle of nowhere and with nothing much to do other than cut peat and count sheep.And itrsquos true that when the wind blows hard and itrsquos dark midway through an October afternoon, even Orkney-born and bred islander Alistair Walker has to admit itrsquos hard to really feel the love for le on the edge of the map.ldquoYou canrsquot be cheery all of the time when the weather is bad then, of course, yoursquore not going to be that happy, he concedes, breaking off from preparing for evening diners at Kirkwall Hotel where he is restaurant manager.ldquoBut, itrsquos still a pretty good le.Indeed, new research suggests that le on some of Scotlandrsquos most remote islands, where le is undoubtedly a little tougher and requires that bit more resilience and determination, is much better for the soul than some of us may have thought.According to the Office for National Statisticsrsquo annual wellbeing study, the islands of Orkney, Shetland and the Western Isles are at the top of the nationrsquos happiest places to live.Meanwhile, people living in towns and cities across the busy central belt with their easy access to entertainment, leisure facilities, a range of employment options and all mod cons, appear to be stuck in the doldrums, among some of the least upbeat citizens in the country.The research had asked , people across the UK to rank their happiness, anxiety, le satisfaction and feeling that what le offers them is worthwhile.When it came to le satisfaction, the Orkney Islands were given the highest rating in Scotland and the second highest in the UK: an impressive . out of .The Western Isles also scored highly at ., while Shetland achieved  out of  for happiness and a mere . out of  for anxiety compared to the Scottish average of ..The three island areas ranked top for persistently recording high levels of well-being across all categories from March  to .The results outpaced Glasgow which managed to score just . for le satisfaction and Edinburgh on ..None of which particularly surprises Alistair, who sampled a taste of le away from Orkney for a spell but soon realised le was far better back on his island home.ldquoIt sounds daft, but itrsquos that lsquohomersquo thing, the place draws you back. Young people go away, they go to university but at one time or another they tend to come back, he says.ldquoOrkney is laid back, therersquos a relaxed lestyle. Yoursquore not going to be spending your time sitting in a traffic jam here.ldquoA big part of it is the community feel. The fact that you know who everyone is, you feel like you can walk down the street and recognise everyone.ldquoPeople stop and speak to each other instead of everyone walking by and not saying hello.ldquoIt makes it special and it draws people back.In Stornoway in the Western Isles where le satisfaction ranks at . out of , and happiness is a contented ., father of two Keith Morrison, , is perfectly happy too.ldquoIsland people are very bad at selling themselves and donrsquot want to be thought of as showing off, which has led to this idea of people being a bit dour, he says.ldquoBut there really is a lot of happiness here.Part of that is thanks to the rugged coastline, the wild moors, lochs and hills. But, he adds, itrsquos also the special way of le.ldquoPeople grow up together, go to school together and work together.ldquoIf yoursquore searching for happiness, the icing on the cake is being able to say to your kids to go out the door and play and not worry about where they are.ldquoTheir friendsrsquo parents are the people you went to school with.ldquoThe pace of le is such a big thing, therersquos no hurry. Butpeople are ambitious and want to do something incredible, then the resources are here to do it too.The new research is not the first time the three island communities have been singled out for their quality of le. Two years ago a childrenrsquos quality of le survey carried out by the Halax named Orkney, Shetland and the Western Isles as the best places to raise children.In particular, it praised Orkneyrsquos low primary school class size, high school spending per pupil, low population density and traffic levels, adding that children there were likely to be surrounded by adults in full-time work and with high personal wellbeing.Another Halax survey last year put Orkney at the top of the places rural places to live in the UK, taking into account a range of factors, from residents health, employment, crime rates and education to home size and the number of pubs.Meanwhile, the search for an improved quality of le has seen a rise in the number of people opting to make Scottish islands their home: the  census revealed , people living on inhabited islands in Scotland, a rise of four per cent on the  census.Mainland Shetland, Orkney, Lewis and Harris and Skye accounted for nearly two-thirds of the total population of Scotlandrsquos islands.ldquoThe image we have is probably the same as for Orkney and Shetland - that itrsquos extreme living and very little is lsquomiddle of the roadrsquo, adds Keith who, along with we Rhoda, is Lewis born and raised.Perhaps as confirmation of the happy vibes that surround Western Islesrsquo living, he has made a living as a musician and producer, and runs Wee Studio Records in Stornoway, home to trio Peat and Diesel, whose punk-style upbeat and quirky take on island music is so popular that it has been dubbed lsquoPeatlemaniarsquo.ldquoItrsquos true therersquos a bit of stuffiness, he adds. ldquoBut there are also some of the happiest people in the world here.ldquoIn summer itrsquos beautul, winter is drastic and dferent, therersquos a erse culture but no matter where you are from you are part of the community. And therersquos wonderful music going on.ldquoYoursquore forced to share your le with others when you live here, he adds. ldquoI love it here.

title: new-guide-highlights-landmarks-benefitted-national-lottery-cash
story: But they share common ground beyond their beauty, as they are among  locations to feature in a celebratory new guide that marks the silver anniversary of the National Lottery and is designed to showcase the fruits of more than half a billion pounds invested into the UKs natural heritage over this period.The lsquoNational Lotteryrsquos Guide to  Amazing Outdoor Adventuresrsquo is UK-wide, featuring rugged coastlines and mountain footpaths, as well as nature reserves, parks and forests.With just days until the lottery turns  ndash on November  ndash the guide highlights some of the UK landmarks that have benefitted from funding during this time, also including Loch Lomond and Trossachs National Park, as well as The Glens of Antrim in Northern Ireland, Snowdonia in Wales and an array of spots in England, including Morecambe Bay and Windermere Jetty Museum.In Scotland, the park at Loch Lomond has received more than pound. million of National Lottery funding and guide readers are encouraged to go mountain biking, hiking or wild camping on the hills and glens of the Trossachs.And up in Sutherland, the Forsinard Flows is regarded as one of Scotlandrsquos most important natural treasures, with the RSPB receiving more than pound. million of National Lottery funding to protect and enhance what is known as Flow Country.There, the RSPB looks after more than , hectares of nature reserve, home to amazing wildle, such as breeding waders, hunting hen harrier or herds of grazing red deer.To mark the anniversary, former Blue Peter presenter, Helen Skelton, led an expedition to the summit of the Ben, joined by a group of young people from the PEEK Project in Glasgows east end, which has received more than pound million of National Lottery funds to aid its work to improve the le chances of children and young people across Scotland through a programme of free play and creative learning.Ms Skelton said: "I loved getting out into the great outdoors with an enthusiastic and excited group of young people. It was exhausting ndash but brilliant."National Lottery players raise over pound million a week for good causes and have contributed so much to the UKrsquos amazing and ied landscapes. I am a huge supporter of people experiencing the great outdoors for themselves. lsquoThe National Lotteryrsquos Guide to  Amazing Outdoor Adventuresrsquo will hopefully inspire people to discover their next adventure."Michaela Collins, chief executive of PEEK, said: ldquoThis was an incredible experience for the young people. Irsquom thrilled that they got a chance to do something so amazing. Funding from The National Lottery players has been crucial to our organization and helped us in our work to improve the lives of children and young people across Scotland.The expedition was in conjunction with the Nevis Landscape Partnership ndash an organisation which works to conserve and enhance the incredible landscape of Ben Nevis and Glen Nevis, thanks to over pound.million of funding from The National Lottery.Every year around , people hike to the summit.Mike Pescod, Chairman of the Nevis Landscape Partnership, said: ldquoWe are delighted to see Ben Nevis included in The National Lotteryrsquos  Amazing Outdoor Adventures Guide. Itrsquos fantastic to see these young people out enjoying the landscape, giving them a really special experience in nature. With the investment from The National Lottery wersquove been able to completely redevelop our mountain path over the last  years, making this experience possible.Over the last  years, The National Lottery has given more than pound million to all of the organisations featured in guide.Drew Bennellick, head of landscapes and nature for The National Lottery Heritage Fund, said: ldquoLooking after our landscapes and reconnecting people with nature has never been more important. Over the last  years, National Lottery funding has had an extraordinary impact on our natural heritage and opened up so many opportunities for people to access the great outdoors.ldquoThese  places to visit are just the tip of the iceberg ndash wersquove funded thousands of projects protecting our landscapes, parks and green spaces and helping people enjoy the great outdoors ndash with all the health and wellbeing benefits they bring. Wersquore hoping the new guide will encourage more people to find their next adventure, no matter how big or small.

title: new-footpath-schiehallion-help-people-enjoy-mountain
story: The lsquofairy hill of the Caledoniansrsquo - Schiehallion - rises from the Perthshire landscape, instantly recognisable thanks to its distinctive pyramid shape.At ,m ,ft, its pin-sharp peak can be seen from as far north as Ben Nevis. Images of its reflection in the deathly still waters of Loch Rannoch have featured in countless calendars and for many Munro baggers, it is a favourite to be saved and savoured as their final summit.One of Scotlandrsquos best-known mountains and at the very heart of the country, Schiehallion is now set to adopt a new role the nationrsquos most inclusive Munro.Work is now underway on a new low-level, circular footpath at Schiehallion that will enable visitors who might normally struggle to fully experience the beauty of Scotlandrsquos outdoors to enjoy its natural beauty up close.The km easy access path and boardwalk will open up the fringes of the mountain to people with mobility problems, families with small children, wheelchairs and prams, and others for whom the peakrsquos uphill trails are too exhausting and challenging.The path, which includes seating areas and interpretation boards along its route explaining the arearsquos wildle and archaeological history, is part of ongoing improvement work being carried out by the Schiehallionrsquos owners, The John Muir Trust.That has already seen extensive repairs to the main path. Pounded by countless pairs of boots, it had stretched to up to  feet wide in sections and left an ugly scar on the hillside. That work led to the first section of the realigned uphill path being specically designed as lsquoeasy accessrsquo.The creation of a new accessible route encircling the base of the mountain is among a growing number of initiatives intended to open Scotlandrsquos countryside and tourist attractions to visitors with a range of mobility or health concerns.Taken together, they could see Scotland position itself as a leader within the potentially lucrative international inclusive tourism market.Last month VisitScotland launched a new guide to help tourism-related businesses become more dementia-friendly in a bid to help them tap into a pound billion lsquodementia poundrsquo sector.The guide highlights the kinds of improvements needed to upgrade infrastructure ndash such as disabled-friendly bathrooms and paths - menus and boost staff knowledge to help attract visitors from a rapidly growing sector.That followed a move earlier this year when the national tourism organisation took guests from two of Europersquos top accessible tour operators to a range of attractions including Stirling Castle, Royal Yacht Britannia, Clydeside Distillery and Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum, to showcase how leading destinations are already catering for the needs of less mobile visitors.It was the first trip of its kind specically designed to highlight Scotlandrsquos inclusive potential and has led to one of the operators, Denmark-based HandiTours, adding Scotland to its package tour programme for the first time. TThe other operator, WeTravel in Belgium, has also included Scottish destinations in its travel guides.Meanwhile, Edinburgh-based Euanrsquos Guide, a disabled access review website, has also worked with the national tourism organisation to produce three accessible itineraries for Scottish destinations, and this summer saw the launch of a new collaborative campaign to promote the Forth Valley as an accessible visitor destination for the first time.Forth Valley Accessibility Tourism Promotion brings together Falkirk and Stirling Councils, Discover Clackmannanshire and Loch Lomond  the Trossachs National Park and has seen a range of itineraries developed to meet the needs of visitors with autism, dementia and mobility issues.The push towards the inclusive tourism sector followed a VisitScotland Travel Trade Survey which revealed more than half of travel agents reported an increase in requests for accessible travel products.One in five people in the UK are disabled, including people with hearing loss and visual impairments, and that disabled tourism tend to take longer trips.In , pound. billion was spent in Scotland on trips where a member of the party had an impairment, including day trips, domestic overnight trips and inbound trips, however, the sector is seen as largely untapped, with potential for growth and improved experiences for guests.Dementia tourism, in particular, is expected to soar in coming years: , people currently live with dementia in Scotland, while the Scottish Government estimates that , people will be newly diagnosed with the condition during .According to VisitScotland, visitors with dementia face a number of challenges including having the confidence to travel, trying to communicate in noisy environments and becoming disorientated when navigating new places or long routes.It says that by becoming dementia-friendly, businesses could join see increased bookings during out of season periods when visitors are more likely to travel, and the potential forbusiness.Marina Di Duca, VisitScotland Inclusive Tourism Manager, said: ldquoParticipating in tourism activities can make signicant improvements to the lives of people living with dementia but taking holidays, visiting attractions and staying in accommodation can be challenging for people living with dementia, their carers and loved ones.ldquoIt is therefore imperative that tourism businesses understand how to support visitors affected by dementia.She added: ldquoCatering for this market also represents a number of benefits for businesses, helping ensure they experience the benefits brought by tourism.ldquoTourism is more than a holiday experience, it is vital to the Scottish economy, reaching every corner of the country, creating jobs and bringing economic and social change.The km Schiehallion path starts and finishes at Braes of Foss car park and is being created by the John Muir Trust and partners including Highland Perthshire Communities Land Trust, and Forestry and Land Scotland, whose land it will cross. The Trust is raising money for the project via its Wild Ways appeal and has secured funding from the Scottish Government and European Union through the Agri-Environment Climate Scheme Improving Public Access Fund.Liz Auty, the John Muir Trustrsquos Schiehallion Land Manager said: ldquoWe are really excited about this project that will allow people of all abilities to experience the hills and enable us to hold educational and public events together with our neighbours, Highland Perthshire Communities Land Trust and Forestry and Land Scotland.Euan MacDonald, co-founder of Euanrsquos Guide, said: ldquoWhile wersquore delighted to see the organisations and groups leading the way in making Scotlandrsquos countryside more accessible, we know that more could be done.ldquoThe lack of information about the routes and not having access to clean working accessible toilets are two major barriers which can prevent disabled people from taking part in outdoors activities.

title: mps-set-vote-john-bercows-successor-commons-speaker
story: Eight candidates are bidding to take on the role following Mr Bercows departure, with the Commons business on Monday dedicated to this election.Deputy Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle is among those strongly tipped to emerge victorious, with fellow Labour MP Harriet Harman - the current longest continuously serving female MP - also predicted to do well.The other six candidates are Dame Rosie Winterton and Dame Eleanor Laing, who also both served as Mr Bercows deputies, Labours Meg Hillier and Chris Bryant , plus Conservatives Sir Edward Leigh and Shailesh Vara.: The  Scottish seats that matter - and the voters wholl decide who takes themCandidates must submit their written nominations between .am and .am on Monday, with their signed declaration needing to be supported by between  and  MPs.The Commons will meet as normal at .pm and each candidate will give a speech - the order decided by drawing lots.A secret ballot among MPs will take place once the speeches have concluded.MPs can only vote for one candidate and the result will be announced in the chamber.Any candidate who receives more than % of the votes will be proposed to the House as Speaker, although MPs will be asked to vote againno candidate meets the threshold.In the second round of voting, candidates who either came last or received fewer than % of the votes will not be on the ballot paper.There is also a -minute period after each round for candidates to withdraw.Ballots will continue until either one MP wins more than % of the votes or only one remains.A motion is then put to the Commons proposing the winner as Speaker and they will take the chairthis is agreed. If not, a vote takes place.Speeches of congratulation are expected to follow the votes.Mr Bercow departed the Speakers chair on October .: Tory MP Ross Thomson stepping down from parliament after groping allegationsThe -year-old entered Parliament in  and held several shadow ministerial positions before taking the Speakers chair on June  , promising to serve "no more than nine years in total".He abandoned that commitment ahead of the  snap election, but allegations of bullying by former members of his staff, denied by the Speaker, led to fresh calls for him to quit.In recent months he also come under fire for a series of controversial Brexit rulings in the chamber which were widely considered to favour Remain supporters.

title: scottish-baftas-stars-gather-celebrate-best-scots-talent
story: A host of stars took to the red carpet at the  Scottish Baftas, which celebrated the very best in film, games and television produced north of the Border over the last year.Wild Rose, which told of a Scottish woman who juggles her job and the demands of parenthood while pursuing her dream of becoming a country music star, was the biggest winner, picking up three awards, including Best Feature Film.:Chernobyl star dedicates best TV actor Bafta Scotland award to victimsLong-running comedy series Still Game won the Outstanding Contribution to Television award, while Alex Ferns picked up the Best Actorprize for his role in hit drama Chernobyl.Newcomer Lorn Macdonald was rewarded with the Best Actorhonour for his performance in Beats, which chronicled the rave movement in early-s Britain.Beth Allan and Hannah Currie won The Best Short Film category for That Joke Isnrsquot Funny Anymore.Among those presenting awards was Line of Duty star Martin Compston.Jude MacLaverty, director of Bafta Scotland, said: ldquoWe are thrilled to celebrate the inspiring work that is being produced in Scotland, and the fact that so much Scottish talent is being recognised internationally. We congratulate all of our winners and nominees.A break-out star of gruelling TV drama Chernobyl has dedicated his best television actor award at the Scottish Baftas to the victims of the nuclear accident.In the acclaimed series, Alex Ferns played miner leader Andrei Glukhov who led his men to prevent further disaster at the nuclear plant.Accepting the award at a ceremony in Glasgow, Ferns, who previously starred in EastEnders as villain Trevor Morgan, joked: "Just when you think your career is f*****, along comes Chernobyl."He added: "Id also like to commemorate Chernobyl and the people that put their lives on the line."Thats what this is all about, I dont care about anything ."Other winners included Trainspotting actress Kelly Macdonald who took the TV actress award for her role in Scottish drama The Victim, who said she was "so privileged" to play her character Anna Dean."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Stars gather for Scottish Bafta Awards","description": "Stars gather for Scottish Bafta Awards","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media xEznozd poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests xEznozd.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": :Still Game stars chuffed to bits over Scottish Baftas awardScottish comedy Still Game won the Outstanding Contribution to Television award, presented by Line Of Duty Star Martin Compston and actor and director David Hayman who have both starred in the show.Compston praised Still Game as "the best Scottish TV show ever made" while First Minister Nicola Sturgeon also paid tribute.Co-creator Ford Kiernan told the PA news agency: "Twenty-one years its been, its been ages - it just means a lot to finally get that sort of recognition at the end."Weve had a couple of Baftas before, oh yes, but were chuffed to bits to be picking this up tonight. Its obviously the work of a whole lot of people."Among the other presenters at the event at the Doubletree Hilton hotel, hosted by broadcaster Edith Bowman, were Outlander stars Sam Heughan and Caitriona Balfe and Derry Girls stars Saoirse-Monica Jackson and Nicola Coughlan.Film Wild Rose picked up the most awards with star Jackie Buckley taking the actress film award, Nicole Taylor winning the Writer Film Television gong while the production also won feature film.Beats actor Lorn Macdonald won Actor Film award, while The Cry took the Television scripted prize and Murder Case won both Features and Factual Series and its director Matt Pinder took the Director Factual award.Pat Rambaut - script supervisor on films such as Local Hero, Bridget Joness Diary and Mona Lisa - was given the outstanding contribution to craftaward.Documentary Yes No: Inside the Indyref won in Specialist Factual, while Real Kashmir F.C. was awarded the Single Documentary prize and was Disclosure: Who Killed Emma  took the Current Affairs trophy.Jon S. Baird won Director Fiction for his film Stan  Ollie, while Observation received the award for Game, with Short Film won by That Joke Isnt Funny Anymore.Entertainment was scooped by Last Commanders and this years Animation category was taken by Love, Death  Robots - Helping Hand.Jude MacLaverty, Bafta Scotland director, said: "It has been a fantastic evening celebrating the very best of Scottish creative talent in Scotland across the film, games, and television industries."We are thrilled to celebrate the inspiring work thats being produced in Scotland, and the fact that so much Scottish talent is being recognised internationally in the screen industries."We would like to offer our warmest congratulations to all our worthy winners and nominees."
